articles.author: Shimin Zhang
articles.description:
Iâ€™m a big fan of movies by J.J. Abrams. I enjoy their tight plots, quippy dialog, and of course: anamorphic lens flares. Filmmakers like Abrams use lens flare to add a dash of â€˜homemadeâ€™ realism to their movies, â€¦
Add a CSS Lens Flare to Photos for a Bright Touch originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Add a CSS Lens Flare to Photos for a Bright Touch

articles.author: Adam Rackis
articles.description:
Content delivery networks, or CDNs, allow you to improve the delivery of your websiteâ€™s static resources, most notably, with CDN caching. They do this by serving your content from edge locations, which are located all over the world. When a â€¦
Adding CDN Caching to a Vite Build originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Adding CDN Caching to a Vite Build

articles.author: Temani Afif
articles.description:
We recently covered creating fancy borders with CSS mask properties, and now we are going to cut the corners with CSS mask and clip-path! A lot of techniques exist to cut different shapes from the corners of any element. â€¦
Tricks to Cut Corners Using CSS Mask and Clip-Path Properties originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: Tricks to Cut Corners Using CSS Mask and Clip-Path Properties

articles.author: Daniel Schwarz
articles.description:
A bookmarklet is a JavaScript-based bookmark that adds to a web browser. Iâ€™d like to show you some awesome web browser hacks to aid your web development workflow and how to convert those hacks into time-saving bookmarklets.
Activating design mode
â€¦
6 Useful Bookmarklets to Boost Web Development originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: 6 Useful Bookmarklets to Boost Web Development

articles.author: Jens Oliver Meiert
articles.description:
You may not use XHTML (anymore), but when you write HTML, you may be more influenced by XHTML than you think. You are very likely writing HTML, the XHTML way.
What is the XHTML way of writing HTML, and what â€¦
Write HTML, the HTML Way (Not the XHTML Way) originally published on CSS-Tricks. You should get the newsletter.

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Marli Mesibov)
articles.description: Storytelling is a powerful tool for any UX designer. It helps create a product and understand the people who use it. In this article, Marli Mesibov takes a real-life example of an app she helped to build in 2017 and explains five steps you can use to help you build a story into your user experience.
articles.title: How To Use Storytelling In UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Paul Boag)
articles.description: Whether you work in-house or run a digital agency, there are occasions when you will consider hiring freelancers to supplement your team. articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Dan Donald)

Message ordering guarantees
Section 4.7 of the AMQP 0-9-1 core specification explains the conditions under which ordering is guaranteed: messages published in one channel, passing through one exchange and one queue and one outgoing channel will be received in the same order that they were sent. RabbitMQ offers stronger guarantees since release 2.7.0.

Messages can be returned to the queue using AMQP methods that feature a requeue parameter (basic.recover, basic.reject and basic.nack), or due to a channel closing while holding unacknowledged messages. Any of these scenarios caused messages to be requeued at the back of the queue for RabbitMQ releases earlier than 2.7.0. From RabbitMQ release 2.7.0, messages are always held in the queue in publication order, even in the presence of requeueing or channel closure.

With release 2.7.0 and later it is still possible for individual consumers to observe messages out of order if the queue has multiple subscribers. This is due to the actions of other subscribers who may requeue messages. From the perspective of the queue the messages are always held in the publication order.
